metadata.case_name: Transferee (Nilakanta Iyer's son) v. Official Receiver

facts.text: Koya Kunju died in or about 1921 leaving widow, two sons and two daughters who jointly carried on ancestral business through eldest son under power of attorney.
Family added tile factory and oil mill to business.
In June-July 1924, sons approached appellant's father (money-lender at Mankompu, 50-60 miles from Quilon) for Rs. 75,000 loan on usufructuary mortgage of immovable properties.
Appellant's father's two sons made enquiries at Quilon about borrowers' status and means.

Usufructuary mortgage Ex. I for Rs. 75,000 dated August 18, 1924 executed by heirs of Koya Kunju; purpose: family necessity for trade/business; 9% interest via lease back at Rs. 6,750 annual rent; properties unencumbered.
Lease deed granting lease back to mortgagors same date August 18, 1924; if rent arrears for two years, lessees surrender properties.
Hypothecation bond to Kadir Moideen Rowther for Rs. 78,859-15-0 on August 30, 1924 hypothecating equity of redemption and other properties to liquidate outstanding debts from 1911 dealings.
S. M. Sheikh Mohideen Rowther applied September 15, 1924 to adjudicate mortgagors as insolvents, citing transactions as acts of insolvency.

First counter petitioner (eldest son) in affidavit admitted joint business, debts including mortgage and hypothecation totaling 2.5 lakhs, assets worth not less than 7 lakhs; denied acts of insolvency.
District Judge adjudged counter petitioners insolvents on August 29, 1927.
Official Receiver appointed interim receiver October 19, 1924.
Interim receiver reported February 11, 1925: mortgaged properties yield Rs. 1,600/year; insolvents willing to pay Rs. 6,750 rent.
Rent arrears over two years; mortgagee sued for arrears, interest, possession; decreed; mortgagee in possession since.
Official Receiver applied March 28, 1928 to annul transfers in Schedule A (usufructuary mortgage, lease, hypothecation) under ss.35,36 Insolvency Regulation.
No allegations of lack of bona fides or consideration in Receiver's petition para.4.
Mortgagee's son opposed: bona fide for value, misjoinder, limitation, estoppel.
Issue 1: Whether otti and lease deeds executed in good faith and for valuable consideration.
District Judge (Mrs. Anna Chandy) held res judicata per Mahomed Siddique; on merits, only Rs.20,000 paid, not bona fide; annulled.
High Court: no res judicata; full Rs.75,000 paid; but not good faith (no due care); appeal dismissed.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court.
Evidence: CPWs 1-7 (1930-1932); allegation of only Rs.20,000 first in 1933 by CPW8 (insolvent).
Proceedings dilatory: annulment from 1928 to 1944 (16 years).
Payments: Rs.55,000 cash August 20, 1924 (Ex.LIV); Rs.20,000 in 6 instalments Sep 1-9, 1924 (Exs.LVII-LVIII, LIXa etc.); supported by books Exs.LXVII-LXXII.
Some payments to creditors: CPW4 Rs.2,500 (Ex.LIXa); CPW3 Rs.1,500 (Ex.LXIVa).
Insolvents owed Imperial Bank Rs.30,000-40,000; portion paid via mortgage money/ornaments sale.
Receiver (CPW13) examined 1943; no thorough enquiry into accounts/insolvents.
Properties worth ~1.5 lakhs per Receiver.

legal_issues.text: Whether the usufructuary mortgage Ex.I dated August 18, 1924 is within the third exception to s.35 of Travancore Regulation VIII of 1090 (Insolvency Regulation): made in favour of purchaser/incumbrancer in good faith and for valuable consideration.
Burden of proof: lies on Official Receiver to prove transaction not in good faith and for valuable consideration.
Whether adjudication order dated August 29, 1927 finding acts of insolvency (including Ex.I) is res judicata barring challenge in annulment proceedings.
Definition of 'good faith': due care and attention (Travancore General Clauses Act) or honesty (Indian General Clauses Act).

petitioner_arguments.text: Transaction bona fide for valuable consideration; burden on Receiver; misjoinder, limitation, estoppel.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.35 Insolvency Regulation; Official Assignee v. Khoo Saw Cheow

petitioner_arguments.text: Full Rs.75,000 paid: cash Rs.55,000 + instalments; supported by receipts, books, creditor witnesses.
Enquiries made by sons via relation CPW6 and merchants; borrowers reputed solvent with unencumbered properties >1 lakh.
No prior relation; no knowledge of insolvency; honest transaction for business.
Joint trial with hypothecation prejudiced; >2 years from adjudication.

respondent_arguments.text: Transfers void under ss.35,36 Insolvency Regulation.
Adjudication order res judicata: acts of insolvency included Ex.I to defeat/delay creditors.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta

respondent_arguments.text: Only Rs.20,000 paid, not full consideration.
Not good faith: no due care/attention in enquiries despite known debts.

court_reasoning.text: Burden on Receiver to prove not good faith/valuable consideration per Privy Council precedents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts below erred placing burden on transferee.

court_reasoning.text: No res judicata: adjudication found acts by transferor, not transferee's knowledge/bona fides.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if applicable, no finding on transferee's good faith.

court_reasoning.text: Full Rs.75,000 consideration proved by receipts, books, creditors; Receiver failed to disprove.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court finding correct; late allegation by insolvents rejected.

court_reasoning.text: Good faith means honesty, not mere due care (repugnant to insolvency context); protects honest creditors.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Indian General Clauses Act test applies over Travancore's.

court_reasoning.text: Transferee honest: no prior relation, enquiries showed good reputation/assets; no suspicion of insolvency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence transferee privy to debtors' intent.

court_reasoning.text: Enquiries sufficient for stranger lender; no need to list creditors/pay directly.

holdings.text: Burden on Receiver under s.35 to prove lack of good faith/valuable consideration.
No res judicata from adjudication order re transferee's bona fides.
Good faith in insolvency = honesty; transferee acted honestly.
Transaction within third exception to s.35; not annulled.

precedents_cited.case_name: Official Assignee v. Khoo Saw Cheow
precedents_cited.relevance: Burden on assignee to prove lack of good faith/consideration under similar s.50.

precedents_cited.case_name: Official Receiver v. P.L.K.M.R.M. Chettyar Firm
precedents_cited.relevance: Reaffirmed burden under Provincial Insolvency Act s.53.
Receiver must prove transferee knew of insolvency even if entire assets transferred.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Adjudication conclusive on transfer as act of insolvency but not transferee's bona fides.

precedents_cited.case_name: Official Assignee of Madras v. O.R.M.O.R.S. Firm
precedents_cited.relevance: Overruled by Privy Council on res judicata.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ex parte Learoyd In re Foulds

statutes_cited.name: Travancore Regulation VIII of 1090 (1915) (Insolvency Regulation)
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfers void against receiver if insolvent within 2 years unless good faith/valuable consideration (third exception); annulment.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore-Cochin General Clauses Act II of 1072 (1897)/VII of 1125 (1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Good faith = due care; but repugnant in insolvency context.

statutes_cited.name: Indian General Clauses Act X of 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Good faith = honestly (negligence irrelevant); appropriate for insolvency.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments below set aside; usufructuary mortgage Ex.I and lease binding on insolvents' estate; transaction not annulled under s.35.

key_quotes.text: the onus is upon the Official Assignee to prove that a conveyance which he was seeking to set aside was not made in good faith and for valuable consideration.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes burden of proof on Receiver.

key_quotes.text: the test of honesty is more appropriate than the test of due care and attention.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines good faith for insolvency proceedings.

key_quotes.text: Unless it is found that the transferee was wanting in bona fides in respect of the transaction in question, he cannot be affected by the dishonest course of conduct of the transferor.
key_quotes.speaker: court
